facts.text: Suit instituted against a number of persons for partition of four annas Milkiat interest in Touzi No. 702, Tappa Haveli, Pargana Maheshi, District Champaran, Bihar.

facts.text: High Court in appeal modified the decree reducing the plaintiffs share to Rs. 0-1-4 interest only.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld the trial courts preliminary decree on 5th October 1953.

facts.text: Bihar Land Reforms Act of 1950 was passed effecting far-reaching changes in land tenure and holdings.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile the Bihar Land Reforms Act of 1950 effecting far-reaching changes in the incidents of land tenure and land holdings had been passed.

facts.text: Object of the Act was to cause transference to the State of interests of proprietors and tenure-holders in land.

anchor.surface_text: As is well known the object of the Act was to cause transference to the State of the interest of proprietors and tenure-holders in land as also of the mortgagees and lessees of such interests including interests in trees, forests, fisheries, jalkars, ferries, hats, bazars, mines and minerals.

concepts.interpretation: Enables State to declare vesting of estates or tenures.

anchor.surface_text: The consequences ,of such vesting are set-forth in s. 4. Under cl.  a  Such estate or tenure including the interests of the proprietor or tenure-holder in any building or part of a building comprised in such estate or tenure and used primarily as office or cutchery for the collection of rent of such estate or tenure, and his interest in trees, forests, fisheries, jalkars, sairati interest as also his interest in all sub-soil including any rights in mines and minerals whether discovered or undiscovered, or whether being worked or not, inclusive of such rights of a lessee of mines and minerals, comprised in such estate or tenure  other than the interests of raiyats or under-raiyats  shall, with effect from the date of vesting, vest absolutely in the State free from all encumbrances and such proprietor or tenure-holder shall cease to have any interest in such estate or tenure, other than the interests expressly saved by or under the provisions of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Consequences of vesting: estate vests absolutely in State free from encumbrances except saved interests.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s or tenures of a proprietor or tenure-holder specified therein would pass to and become vested in the State. The companysequences ,of such vesting ar

anchor.surface_text: S. 6 of the Act provides for such saving and the relevant portion thereof runs as follows On and from the date of vesting all lands used for agricultural or horticultural purposes, which were in khas possession of an intermediary on the date of such vesting, including-  a   i  proprietors private lands let out under a lease for a term of years or under a lease from year to year landlords privileged lands let out under a registered lease for a term exceeding one year or under ,a lease, written or oral, for, a period of one year or less, referred to in section 43 of the Chota Nagpur Tenancy Act, 1908,  b  lands used for agricultural or horticultural purposes and held in the direct possession of a temporary lessee of an estate or tenure and cultivated by himself with his own stock or by his own servants or by hired labour or with hired stock, and  c  lands used for agricultural or horticultural purposes forming the subject matter of a subsisting mortgage on the redemption of which the intermediary is entitled to recover khas possession thereof shall be deemed to be settled by the State with such intermediary and he shall be entitled to retain possession thereof and hold them as a raiyat under the State having occupying rights in respect of such lands subject to the payment of such fair and equitable rent as may be determined by the Collector in the prescribed manner.
There is no dispute that bakasht lands fall under categories  b  and  c .

concepts.interpretation: Bakasht lands fall under categories b and c of s.6(1).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: d  c  lands used for agricultural or horticultural purposes

anchor.surface_text: Referring to the definition of Khas possession in s. 2 k  of the Act as meaning the possession of such proprietor or tenure- holder by cultivating such land or carrying on horticultural operations thereon himself with his own stock or by his own servants or by hired labour or with hired stock.

concepts.interpretation: Khas possession means possession by cultivating oneself with own stock/servants/hired.

issues.text: whether the direction of the High Court that the partition suit launched in 1943 should be allowed to proceed in view of the provisions of s. 6 of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 which came into force on 25th September, 1950, is correct

anchor.surface_text: The only question involved in this appeal is, whether the direction of the High Court that the partition suit launched in 1943 should be allowed to proceed in view of the provisions of s. 6 of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 which came into force on 25th September,

issues.text: whether the consequence of s. 6 was to put an end to the character of the possession of the bakasht lands to the malik by causing them to vest in the State and simultaneously creating a tenancy in favour of the person in khas possession thereof

anchor.surface_text: The broad proposition which was advanced before the High Court and rejected by it and reiterated before us is that the consequence of s. 6, was to put an end to the character of the possession of the bakasht lands to the malik by causing them to vest in the State and simultaneously creating a tenancy in favour of the person in khas possession thereof.

issues.text: whether the appellants had laid a claim which a cosharer could not put forward except by pleading ouster or any other independent ground

anchor.surface_text: In this case we have to consider whether the appellants had laid a claim which a cosharer could not put forward except by pleading ouster or any other independent ground. Even if they were in actual khas possession within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act it must be held that the plaintiff who was a cosharer was in constructive possession through the appellants as under the law possession of one cosharer is possession of all the cosharers.

arguments.court_reasoning: Co-sharer's constructive possession through actual possessors means s.6 benefits all co-sharers.

arguments.claim: Point settled by Full Bench that bakasht lands deemed settled with ex-proprietor in khas possession and co-sharer not in actual possession has claim on basis of constructive possession.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute that bakasht lands fall under categories b and c . We are not here concerned with category c and have quoted it to appreciate some decisions relied on where there are references to that category. This question has engaged the attention of the Patna High Court more than once and it would appear that the views expressed in different cases have not been uniform.

arguments.claim: Mere subsisting title to possession over land on date of vesting does not amount to khas possession for purposes of s.6.

anchor.surface_text: this is also inconsistent with the reasoning of the Full Bench by which constructive pos- session is treated as within the concept of khas possession.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff as co-sharer was in constructive possession through appellants as possession of one co-sharer is possession of all co-sharers.

anchor.surface_text: In this case we have to consider whether the appellants had laid a claim which a cosharer could not put forward except by pleading ouster or any other independent ground. Even if they were in actual khas possession within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act it must be held that the plaintiff who was a cosharer was in constructive possession through the appellants as under the law possession of one cosharer is possession of all the cosharers.

arguments.claim: Deeming provision of s.6 must enure for the benefit of all who in the eye of law would be regarded as in actual possession.

anchor.surface_text: The deeming provision of s. 6 must therefore enure for the benefit of all who in the eye of law would be regarded as in actual possession.

arguments.claim: Appellants do not claim to be trespassers nor claim title adversely to plaintiff respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants do not claim to be trespassers on the property neither did they claim any title to the lands adversely to the plaintiff respondent.

holdings.text: it must be held that the plaintiff who was a cosharer was in constructive possession through the appellants as under the law possession of one cosharer is possession of all the cosharers

anchor.surface_text: Even if they were in actual khas possession within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act it must be held that the plaintiff who was a cosharer was in constructive possession through the appellants as under the law possession of one cosharer is possession of all the cosharers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants in actual possession but as co-sharers; no plea of ouster or adverse title; standard co-sharer possession doctrine applies to deem khas possession under s.6

holdings.text: The deeming provision of s. 6 must therefore enure for the benefit of all who in the eye of law would be regarded as in actual possession

anchor.surface_text: The deeming provision of s. 6 must therefore enure for the benefit of all who in the eye of law would be regarded as in actual possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 settlement with intermediary in khas possession extends to co-sharers via constructive possession; enables partition suit to proceed post-vesting

holdings.text: We consider that this equation of the right to possession with khas possession is not justified by principle or authority

anchor.surface_text: We consider that this equation of the right to possession with khas possession is not justified by principle or authority. Besides this is also inconsistent with the reasoning of the Full Bench

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes mere title/right to possession from actual khas possession under s.2(k) and s.6; follows prior SC precedents (Surajnath, Ram Ran); approves Full Bench constructive possession inclusion

holdings.text: constructive possession is treated as within the concept of khas possession

anchor.surface_text: this is also inconsistent with the reasoning of the Full Bench by which constructive pos- session is treated as within the concept of khas possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses Patna HC Full Bench (Mahanth Sukhdeo Das) holding that constructive possession qualifies as khas possession under s.6 for bakasht lands

holdings.text: The case is not therefore an authority for the proposition that a cosharers constructive possession is to be ignored under s. 6 (1) (c) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The case is not therefore an authority for the proposition that a cosharers constructive possession is to be ignored under s. 6 1 c of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior SC case (Ram Ran Bijai Singh) as not applicable to co-sharer constructive possession under s.6(1)(c)

precedents.citation: Mahanth Sukhdeo Das. v. Kashi Prasad Tewari and Shrideo Misra v. Ramsewak Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: So far as the said High Court is companycerned the point was settled by a decision of the Full Bench in Mahanth Sukhdeo Das. v. Kashi Prasad Tewari and Shrideo Misra v. Ramsewak Singh 1 . The main questions before the Full Bench were whether on the vesting of an estate which was mortgaged at the material time the bakasht lands therein which are deemed to be settled with the ex-proprietor in khas possession would form substituted security for the purpose of the mortgage, and whether a companysharer proprietor number in actual possession of such lands had Any claim thereto on the basis of his companystructive possession.

precedents.case_name: Mahanth Sukhdeo Das v Kashi Prasad Tewari
precedents.cited_proposition: bakasht lands deemed settled with ex-proprietor in khas possession form substituted security for mortgage and cosharer proprietor not in possession has claim based on constructive possession
precedents.cited_holding: High Court answered both questions in the affirmative

anchor.surface_text: One of the earliest cases in which this Court had to interpret s. 6 of the Act was that of Surajnath Ahir v. Prithinath Singh 2   . There the question which engaged the attention of this Court was whether the appellants who had originally gone into possession on the strength of a mortgage lost their right to continue in possession even if they claimed to be trespassers after the redemption of their mortgage by reason of the estate vesting in the State on the passing of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: mortgagees continuing in possession after redemption do not lose right under s.6 due to vesting; khas possession requires actual cultivation not mere title
precedents.cited_holding: no subsisting mortgage on vesting date; mere title to possession does not amount to khas possession under s.6(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: Rejecting the construction put on the expression khas possession by the High Court in Brijnandan Singh v. Jamuna Prasad 1  it was said The mere fact that a proprietor has a subsisting title to possession over certain land on the date of vesting would number make that land under his khas possession.

precedents.cited_proposition: construction of khas possession as including mere subsisting title to possession

precedents.citation: Ram Ran Bijai Singh v. Behari Singh alias Bagandha Singh 2

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench decision of the Patna High Court, came up for consideration by this Court in Ram Ran Bijai Singh v. Behari Singh alias Bagandha Singh 2 . There the appellants before this, Court were the plaintiffs who had filed a suit for a declaration that a certain plot of land was their zeraiti land and that the persons impleaded as the defendants 1st and 2nd parties had number right or title thereto and for recovery of possession of the said land by dispossessing them therefrom.

precedents.case_name: Ram Ran Bijai Singh v Behari Singh alias Bagandha Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: zeraiti lands of plaintiffs do not vest due to s.6; possession of contesting tenants not on behalf of mortgagor after redemption
precedents.cited_holding: equation of right to possession with khas possession not justified; constructive possession concept inconsistent with adverse possession of tenants

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made in the course of arguments to the Full Bench decision in Sukhdeo Dass case 3  and it was submitted that a mortgagee continuing in possession of the mortgaged property after payment of the mortgage amount must hold the same on behalf of the mortgagor and in trust for him. Counsel further relied on certain observations in the judgment of the Full Bench in aid of his proposition and submitted on the basis thereof that even the possession of a trespasser who had number perfected his title by adverse possession for the requisite period of time under the Limitation Act should be considered as in khas possession of the true owner.

precedents.case_name: Mahanth Sukhdeo Das v Kashi Prasad Tewari
precedents.cited_proposition: mortgagee continuing in possession after payment holds on behalf of mortgagor; trespasser possession as khas possession of owner

precedents.citation: S. P. Shah v. B. N. Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants also referred us to a recent decision of this Court in S. P. Shah v. B. N. Singh 1  in aid of his contention that the true effect of s. 6 of the Act was to create a new right ,of tenancy in favour of the person in khas possession and consequently even if the plaintiff in the partition suit had a right to ask for demarcation of his Rs. 0-4-0 share of the bakasht lands before the passing of the Land Reforms Act, he could number pursue his claim by a prayer that he be considered a tenant along with those who were in actual khas possession.

precedents.case_name: S P Shah v B N Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: s.6 creates new tenancy right for person in khas possession independent of prior rights

precedents.citation: P. L. Reddy v. L. L. Reddy 1

anchor.surface_text: Even if they were in actual khas possession within the meaning of s. 2 k  of the Act it must be held that the plaintiff who was a cosharer was in constructive possession through the appellants as under the law possession of one cosharer is possession of all the cosharers. We see number reason to hold that the observations of this Court to the above effect in P. L. Reddy v. L. L. Reddy 1  are number applicable to the case before us.

precedents.case_name: P L Reddy v L L Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: possession of one cosharer is possession of all cosharers
